G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Emily Johnson, and respectfully files this Complaint for Modification pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and requests that this Honorable Court modify the custody and parenting time provisions of the Judgment entered on May 15, 2016.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 208, § 31, modifications to custody and parenting time arrangements must be based on the best interests of the child.

McMahon v. McMahon, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 50.raw_text: McMahon v. McMahon, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 504 (1991)
McMahon v. McMahon, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 50.proposition: The best interests of Sophie Smith require substantially increased time with the Plaintiff, consistent with Massachusetts appellate precedent affirming that strong and meaningful relationships with both parents best serve a child’s welfare.
McMahon v. McMahon, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 50.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns division of military retirement pay and the court’s jurisdiction under the Uniformed Services Former Spouses’ Protection Act; it does not address custody, parenting time, or the best interests of a child. There is no discussion of the value of a child having strong and meaningful relationships with both parents or any best-interests analysis. Therefore, it cannot be used as Massachusetts appellate authority for increasing a child’s time with a parent based on such principles.
McMahon v. McMahon, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 50.relevant_excerpt: At the time of the judgment, the judge made findings of fact which show that she considered all factors relevant under G. L. c. 208, § 34. Those findings have a solid basis in the evidence and support the judge’s rationale for the division. See Bowring v. Reid, 399 Mass. 265, 267-268 (1987). In her supplemental findings, the judge expressly states that Susan is “entitled to more than fifty percent of the marital estate.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The best interests of Sophie Smith require substantially increased time with the Plaintiff, consistent with Massachusetts appellate precedent affirming that strong and meaningful relationships with both parents best serve a child’s welfare.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion’s central holdings concern (1) rejecting any presumption in favor of joint physical custody and (2) applying the ‘real advantage’ standard to allow the custodial parent to remove the children to Greece, despite a resulting reduction in the father’s contact. The court expressly refuses to presume that shared physical custody—or maximized time with both parents—is in a child’s best interests, and instead ties the child’s welfare to the custodial parent’s well‑being. This does not affirm a principle that the child’s best interests require substantially increased time with both parents; it supports almost the opposite.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt:
“We reject the husband’s assertion that the law of the Commonwealth favors or should presumptively favor joint physical custody… There is no apparent reason to believe that joint physical custody is presumptively preferable in all child custody disputes… The judge was warranted in concluding that physical custody in the wife was in the best interests of each child.”

“[T]he ‘real advantage’ test is grounded on the ‘realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce… [T]he child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.’”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The current Judgment is no longer consistent with Sophie’s best interests, particularly in light of the Plaintiff’s demonstrated stability and Sophie’s expressed needs and preferences.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modification of an existing judgment based on changed circumstances, the child’s current best interests, the plaintiff’s demonstrated stability, and the child’s expressed needs and preferences. Adoption of Hugo is not a post‑judgment modification case; it is an initial best‑interests determination between two adoption plans (a foster mother and an aunt) after parental rights have been terminated. The opinion focuses on deference to the trial judge’s discretionary best‑interests assessment, not on when an existing judgment becomes inconsistent with a child’s current best interests due to later changes in stability or the child’s stated preferences.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … [O]ur attitude toward a trial judge’s decision in a custody appeal is one of substantial deference.”

Schaffer v. Schaffer, 441 Mass. 1016 (20.proposition: A material and substantial change in circumstances justifies modification of existing custody or parenting orders under Massachusetts law.
Schaffer v. Schaffer, 441 Mass. 1016 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion in this case concerns postconviction criminal discovery relating to fingerprint evidence and the standard for obtaining relief under Mass. R. Crim. P. 30(c)(4) and G. L. c. 211, § 3. It does not address family law, custody, parenting orders, or the standard of “material and substantial change in circumstances” for modifying such orders. Therefore it does not support the cited proposition about custody modification under Massachusetts law.
Schaffer v. Schaffer, 441 Mass. 1016 (20.relevant_excerpt: In allowing the Commonwealth’s petition, the single justice concluded that Jones had failed to satisfy his burden of establishing a prima facie case for relief, a prerequisite for the allowance of a motion for discovery pursuant to rule 30 (c) (4). See Commonwealth v. Tague, 434 Mass. 510, 519 (2001), cert. denied, 534 U.S. 1146 (2002). This court will not reverse the judgment of a single justice absent an abuse of discretion or other clear error of law. See Palaza v. Superior Court, 393 Mass. 1001, 1002 (1984).

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently emphasize the importance of fostering close and frequent contact between children and both parents when doing so aligns with their best interests.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames custody determinations around the child’s best interests and emphasizes that a key factor is whether a parent will support, rather than undermine, the child’s relationship with the other parent. The court approves the trial judge’s reasoning that when distance requires sole physical custody, it is in the child’s best interests to place the child with the parent who can support the involvement of both parents, and it upholds a visitation schedule providing frequent contact with the noncustodial parent. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts courts stress fostering close and frequent contact with both parents when consistent with the child’s best interests.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term, and if sole physical custody must be awarded because of geographic distance between parents, ‘it is in the best interests of a child to be in the sole custody of the parent who can support the involvement of both parents rather than with the parent who alienates the child from the other parent.’ … The judge’s custody order gave Rose frequent contact with Jill, including parenting time one weekend per month in Massachusetts, five weeks in the summer, school vacations, holidays, Web camera sessions three evenings per week, and telephone calls once per week.”

Adoption of Abby, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 816.raw_text: Adoption of Abby, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 816 (2005)
Adoption of Abby, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 816.proposition: The Court is authorized to consider expert testimony regarding a child’s emotional and psychological needs.
Adoption of Abby, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 816.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses use of a psychologist and a bonding expert, but only in the context of criticizing the sufficiency of the evidence regarding parental unfitness and the weight given to bonding. It does not state or analyze any rule about the court’s authority to consider expert testimony on a child’s emotional or psychological needs. The case therefore does not serve as authority for the claimed proposition, even if such testimony happened to be part of the record.
Adoption of Abby, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 816.relevant_excerpt: “While we do not question the judge’s finding that Abby would be traumatized by separation from the foster parents, this finding, while supportable, does not suffice to meet the standards that are required if severance of bonds is to be ‘a decisive factor’ in termination of parental rights. See Adoption of Katharine, 42 Mass. App. Ct. at 30-31. In such a case, ‘a judge would be bound in findings to describe the nature of the bonds formed, why serious psychological harm would flow from the severance of those bonds, what means to alleviate the harm had been considered, and why those means were determined to be inadequate.’”

Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598 (1976).proposition: The Court is authorized to consider expert testimony regarding a child’s emotional and psychological needs.
Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion deals with court‑appointed guardians ad litem and their investigative reports in custody cases, and holds that such investigators must be available for cross-examination. It briefly references Fed. R. Evid. 706 about court‑appointed experts, but the case itself does not discuss, authorize, or analyze the use of expert testimony about a child’s emotional or psychological needs. Thus it is not authority for a proposition about considering expert psychological testimony; its holding concerns cross-examination of a guardian ad litem’s report.
Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598 (1976).relevant_excerpt: We are mindful of the court’s need for assistance in arriving at a just resolution of custody cases. There is no question that court-appointed investigators can help a judge to determine what is in the best interests of a child, “[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided.” … In order to determine adequately the reliability and accuracy of a report, we believe that, as a matter of sound judicial policy, the parties should have the opportunity to rebut the report, including the right to cross-examine the investigator… We note that Rule 706 of the Federal Rules of Evidence provides that a court-appointed expert may be called to testify…

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Where a child expresses a well-reasoned preference, Massachusetts courts consistently consider that preference in determining custody arrangements.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss, analyze, or apply the child’s own expressed custodial preference at all. The only mention of a child’s preference appears indirectly in a quotation from the ALI Principles in a footnote listing factors other jurisdictions consider, not as a Massachusetts holding or requirement. The decision focuses on the best-interests standard, primary caretaker/stability considerations, and statutory factors under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a), not on giving weight to a child’s well-reasoned preference, so it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about consistent consideration of such preferences in Massachusetts custody cases.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: Section 2.08(1) of the American Law Institute’s Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution (2002) (ALI Principles) states, in pertinent part, that custody should be awarded “so that the proportion of custodial time the child spends with each parent approximates the proportion of time each parent spent performing caretaking functions for the child prior to the parents’ separation or . . . before the filing of the action.” The exceptions to this guideline are (a) that the award of custody should align with any “uniform rule of statewide application”; (b) that the award should respect the “firm and reasonable preferences” of a child of a certain (undefined) age; …

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.proposition: Where a child expresses a well-reasoned preference, Massachusetts courts consistently consider that preference in determining custody arrangements.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on parental unfitness, standard of proof, and the ability to draw adverse inferences from parents’ failure to testify in a care and protection proceeding. It does not discuss, analyze, or rely on any child’s custodial preference as a factor in the custody determination. The only references to the older child’s statements concern his fear and reports of abuse, not a well‑reasoned custodial preference, so the case cannot be cited as authority that Massachusetts courts consistently consider a child’s well‑reasoned preference in custody decisions.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the older child is aggressive and that this characteristic stems from fear. In addition, he found that the child did not view his environment as safe, could not control his impulses, and had a poor self-image. On several occasions, the judge found, the child had expressed either reluctance or unwillingness to visit his parents because of fear of his father. The judge adopted the opinion of the psychologist at Children’s Hospital Medical Center, that the son needed an emotionally stable home environment unavailable to him in the home of his parents.
